title: Trump foes Kathy Griffin, Bette Midler celebrate formal impeachment inquiry
text:
Naturally, Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi's Tuesday announcement that the House of Representatives would begin a formal impeachment inquiry into whether President Donald Trump encouraged a foreign government to investigate his political rival, caught the attention of celebrities with some celebrating and others standing by him.

And famous names are beginning to respond to the a five-page transcript released Wednesday, from a July phone chat between Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky. During the call lasting half an hour, Trump repeatedly pressed the president of Ukraine to re-open an investigation into a Ukrainian energy company to focus on any involvement by Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden and his son, Hunter, according to the transcript.

"Republicans should put their hand on their heart, remember their Oath to defend the Constitution, and ask themselves one question: 'If Obama asked a foreign leader to work w/his AG & personal lawyer to investigate a political opponent, what would I do?' " tweeted political commentator Ana Navarro-Cárdenas.

Some stars were in favor of the formal impeachment inquiry while others seem to roll their eyes at the move.

Kathy Griffin, who created a stir when she posed with a mock severed Trump head in 2017, celebrated with a GIF of her dancing and the hashtag "#ImpeachTrump".

Bette Midler, posted a photo in a fancy gown.

"IT’S A FORMAL #IMPEACHMENT INQUIRY! THAT’S WHY I’M WEARING MY FANCIEST DRESS!!"

IT’S A FORMAL #IMPEACHMENT INQUIRY! THAT’S WHY I’M WEARING MY FANCIEST DRESS!! pic.twitter.com/HdUhPPBHDk — Bette Midler (@BetteMidler) September 25, 2019

Alyssa Milano tweeted "WOOOOOOHOOOOOOO!" in response to Pelosi's news. She also responded to a 2014 inquiry from Trump asking, "Are you allowed to impeach a president for gross incompetence?"

"Yup," she replied Tuesday.

Meghan McCain defends Chrissy Teigen after President Trump targets Teigen, John Legend

"View" co-host Meghan McCain shared her opinion on "What What Happens Live with Andy Cohen."

"If President Trump did in fact try and bribe the Ukraine and the President of the Ukraine to get information on Joe Biden and his son, this is something that obviously should – I don't know impeachment level – but it should definitely be investigated," she said.

Author Stephen King, an outspoken critic of Trump's, tweeted: "Like Rep. Pelosi, I haven't seen the point of a House impeachment proceeding when the McConnell-led Senate won't convict. But with this Ukraine business, Trump has gone too far and must be brought to heel. For the good of America, impeach now."

Chelsea Handler took pleasure in the timing of the news on the social media site.

"It’s a truly beautiful thing that #ImpeachTrump and #NationalVoterRegistrationDay are both happening on the same day," she shared. "Mazel."

Actor George Takei also feels consequences are necessary.

"People ask what the point of impeachment is if the senate will never remove Trump from office," he posted to Twitter. "I say, the point is to enforce the constitutional consequences of Trump’s abuse of office. If the House had not moved to impeach after this, then our constitution would mean nothing."

Anthony Scaramucci, who very briefly served as the White House communications director in 2017, thanked Pelosi and shared a quote attributed to philosopher Jean-Jacques Rousseau. "Patience is bitter, but it’s fruit is sweet."

Jon Voight attacks 'radical left,' hails Trump as 'the greatest president of this century'

There were also those in Trump's corner.

Singer/songwriter Charlie Daniels voiced his support for thepresident Wednesday morning.

"Donald Trump is the first president I ever remember standing in front of the United Nations and proclaiming the greatness of America and his intentions to keep it that way," the "Devil Went Down to Georgia," artist tweeted. "He chops the log and lets the chips fly wherever they need to fall."
description: Some celebrities are in favor of the formal impeachment inquiry into President Trump, announced Tuesday. Others seem to be rolling their eyes.
